conclusion: Let A be the cross-sectional area of the cylinder.
A = V / H because each chamber initially occupies height H.
The diaphragm will just start to rise when the upward force of the gas in the lower chamber exceeds that in the upper chamber by the diaphragm’s weight.
With x defined in the statement, mg / A = mg H / V = p x.
At the instant the diaphragm starts to lift, P_lower = P_upper + mg / A = p + p x = p(1 + x).
The upper chamber has remained at its original state (p, V, T) up to this moment, so P_upper = p.
The cylinder walls, piston and diaphragm are insulating; hence every change of the gas in each chamber is quasistatic and adiabatic.
For an ideal monatomic gas (helium) γ = 5/3.
Applying P V^γ = constant to the lower chamber between its initial state (p, V) and the state just before the diaphragm moves (P_lower, V₀), p V^γ = P_lower V₀^γ.
Insert P_lower from P_lower = p(1 + x): V₀ = V [1 / (1 + x)]^{1/γ} = V (1 + x)^{−1/γ}.
The volume of the lower chamber when the gas first leaks past the diaphragm is V₀ = V (1 + x)^{−3/5}, where x = mgH / (pV).
